newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Milburn sees slowing building activity.
newsitem.headline: Milburn sees slowing building activity.

text.p: Cement maker Milburn New Zealand Ltd said on Friday it expected tight monetary conditions and political uncertainty to constrict building activity.

"High current interest rates and political uncertainty could dampen New Zealand construction activity. The upward trend of residential building in the last year is expected to level off over the last six months," the company said.
"Results for the second half of the year are likely to be similar to those of the corresponding period in 1995."
Milburn earlier reported interim net profit of NZ$12.42 million, compared with $12.26 million for the previous first half. Its full-year 1995 net profit was $22.8 million.
The half-year result was after absorbing a $2.171 million operating loss (up from $1.172 million in 1995) in the group's associate companies in China.

Milburn said the volume of cement sold by the Chinese Golden Cat Cement Company, in which it has a 25 percent interest, was on budget for the half year but prices remained depressed due to tight government credit restrictions.
Distribution and raw material costs had also risen over the half-year, but there were signs the austerity period was ending and a phase of renewed economic activity lay ahead.
